p.text: [p]By the year 2035, the United States has been split into three hostile provinces – Dorado, Rebellium, and Turtalia. You are a spy working for the Turtalian democracy and you must escape from the hostile Dorado.[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="1"][/p] [p]You are one of the leaders of a spy mission operating in the country of Dorado. You have just broken out of a maximum security prison run by the Doradan Secret Police. Your escape has only just begun.[/p] [p]Now you and your group must make it to safety in Turtalia, which is more than a thousand miles away over semidesert land and vast mountains.[/p] [p]The year is A.D. 2035. A combination of civil wars and foreign attacks has split the United States into three hostile political areas – Dorado, Rebellium, and Turtalia.[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="2"][/p] [p]Dorado, where you have been imprisoned, extends from roughly the border of southern California east to the Mississippi River; north to approximately the borders of Utah, Colorado, Kansas, and Missouri; and south into Mexico.[/p] [p]Dorado is controlled by a trio of army officers. They are mean and grasping, interested only in power and wealth. They command by fear, terrorism, and torture. Their motto is ``Totalitarian Freedom Forever.'' The firing squads have been busy in Dorado.[/p]

[p]The second region is called Rebellium and occupies all territory east of the Mississippi. It is a haphazard collection of minor city states that you feel offers no real help in the struggle with Dorado. Turtalia, which you are trying to reach, is made up of the mountain states north of Arizona and the northern plain states, extending into Canada. The capitol of Turtalia is Denver. Turtalia is a democracy run by elected representatives and governed by a panel of five.[/p] [p]Your father is one of the panel of five. He opposed your volunteering to go on a spy mission into Dorado, but you went anyway. You were sure that you, and only you, could get the plans for the Doradan invasion of Turtalia – and you did get them.[/p] [p]The Doradans arrested you, but fortunately they never suspected that you had learned their invasion plans. Your escape from their prison was due to luck more than to good planning.[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="5"][/p] [p]Right now you are hiding in a barn on a deserted ranch. You're about seven miles north of what used to be called Gallup, New Mexico. There are three other people with you. The most important – except for you, of course – is a thirty-year-old woman who is the leader of the resistance in Dorado. Her name is Mimla. There is a large price on her head. She has to get out![/p] [p]With Mimla is Matt. He's in his early thirties, and it is his responsibility to get her safely out of Dorado.[/p] [p]The third person is a computer specialist named Haven – a silent, nervous man who peers at the world through thick glasses. He is needed in Turtalia to help break Doradan computer codes.[/p] [p]Your father, acting through the resistance organization in Dorado, has arranged an escape flight for the four of you. This morning you are waiting for a Windmaster twin-engined motor-glider to swoop out of the clouds and pick you up.[/p]

[p]You've been waiting for several hours. The plane is now half an hour late. Matt wants to leave.[/p] [p]``I think we should get out of here and head back to town. I don't want to get caught out here,'' he explains.[/p] [p]You look at the clouds, then at the desert.[/p] [p]``I don't know,'' you say finally. ``We're in a pretty good spot right here. We can see anyone coming for quite a distance. I know Bill – the pilot – he's reliable. He'll get here! I think we can wait another half an hour.''[/p]
p.next: If you decide to follow Matt's suggestion and return to town
If you decide to wait another half hour for the plane

p.text: [p]``Welcome aboard, copilot,'' you say to Matt Grinning ear to ear, Matt salutes you. ``At your service, pilot,'' he answers.[/p] [p]While you buckle into the pilot's seat, Matt goes aft to make sure that Mimla and Haven are all set for takeoff. They have made a makeshift cot for Bill and are trying to keep him comfortable. When Matt returns, you quickly run through the instruments and switches with him: altimeter, variometer, fuel gauges, tachometers, engine temperature, throttle controls, engine heater switches, and so on.[/p] [p]Everything is ready. You roll the plane to the end of the strip. Your heart pounds in your chest, but otherwise you feel calm and capable.[/p] [p]Once more you scan the control panel, and then you adjust the throttles. The plane begins rolling down the sandy desert. At the right moment you pull the control column back and you're airborne. You did it![/p] [p]The altimeter spins rapidly as your Windmaster climbs out and heads toward the Sangre de Cristo Mountains. You pass through 15,000 feet, then 16,000, and finally you top out at 17,000 feet. All around you are towering cumulus clouds bulging with moisture. You know that some of them hide violent turbulence that could easily rip the wings from the plane.[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="9"][/p] [p]You jump to your feet. It's a good thing you can wake up quickly. You and Matt join the others outside. The motor-glider has started its engines for the final approach. You admire the slim craft as it swoops down. The Windmaster is a perfect combination: it was designed in 1997 to be a full-performance glider and power plane, and uses almost no gas once it is airborne. You wouldn't mind having a Windmaster of your own.[/p] [p]The plane is close to the ground, ready to land; you can even see Bill at the controls and the Doradan military markings that have been added to the tail as camouflage. Then the plane bobbles, one wing almost catching the ground. Bill straightens it out and touches down. ``I wonder what [em]that[/em] was?'' you think. ``Crosswind, maybe?''[/p] [p]Bill taxis close, swings around, ready for takeoff, and stops, engines idling. Grabbing your stuff, the four of you run to the door. You clamber aboard and throw your gear aft. You'll secure it later. You've got to take off quickly in case the plane was spotted.[/p] [p]``All set, Bill!'' you shout There's no answer from the cockpit. You look at Matt questioningiy. He shrugs his shoulders. You run into the cockpit Bill is slumped over the wheel. He's not breathing! ``Matt!'' you shout. He races in after you.[/p]

[p]Maybe Matt is right Maybe waiting for another half hour would be too risky.[/p] [p]``OK! Let's get out of here,'' you tell him. ``No telling when that plane will get here – look at those clouds. But where do we go when we get back to town, Matt?''[/p] [p]Matt gathers up two canvas sacks filled with personal belongings and several Doradan military manuals and maps that Mimla and Haven have stolen. He shoulders the packs, and then looks at the clouds for a few seconds.[/p] [p]``Not much of a choice,'' he says. ``Back to my friend Julio's place. It's so close to the secret police headquarters that they'll never look for us there.''[/p] [p]You nod in agreement, but in the bottom of your stomach you feel knots of fear at the very mention of the Doradan Secret Police. You'd really like to be as far away from them as possible.[/p] [p]Later that afternoon, you are all in the living room of Julio's thick-walled adobe house in the middle of downtown Albuquerque. From the front window you can see the stark outline of the giass-and-concrete modern building that is Doradan Secret Police Headquarters. Two armed men wearing desert camouflage uniforms stand – feet apart, laser guns at the ready – surveying every person who passes by.[/p]

[p]Mimla is sitting in the far corner of the living room listening intently to a transistor radio. She looks up.[/p] [p]``The plane is down. The Doradans got it over Santa Fe. I hope the pilot doesn't know much – but maybe he's dead.'' Haven cringes in another corner, paler than ever. Matt clenches his fist.[/p] [p]``We have to get out,'' you tell them. ``They'll be on to us before you know it. I've got to get the Doradan invasion plans back to Denver. Anybody got any ideas?''[/p] [p]Mimla rises and walks to the center of the room. She looks at each one of you.[/p] [p]``I think we should split up. I'll go with you,'' she says, staring in your direction. ``OK?''[/p] [p]Matt disagrees. He believes that you four should stay together and try to make it out of town on foot. But it's a long way.[/p]
p.next: If you agree to split up and leave with Mimla
If you argue for staying together

p.text: [p]``Help me with Bill!'' Quickly you undo Bill's seatbelts and ease him out of the seat. He is pale. You check his pulse: almost nothing.[/p] [p]``What's the matter with him?'' Matt asks.[/p] [p]``Heart attack, I think. He looks bad.''[/p] [p]``Oh, no,'' Matt groans. ``Now what do we do?''[/p] [p]``Well, I have some glider training, and I've flown in one of these before,'' you say. ``I think I can fly it out of here.''[/p] [p]``I've had a little power-flight training,'' says Matt ``It sounds like we could do it But maybe we should just forget the plane and use the truck to drive out of here? It would keep us on the ground – the easy way.'' Matt grins at you. You start to smile back, but you're interrupted by Mimla's shouts.[/p] [p]``Somebody's coming!''[/p] [p]You look out and spot a telltale dust cloud.[/p] [p]``They're still a way off,'' Matt says. ``Doradan troops, probably. We'd better decide what to do – and quickly, too!''[/p]
p.next: If you decide to try your skill at piloting the Windmaster and fly out
If you decide to take the truck and risk getting caught on the ground

p.text: [p]``It's too soon to give up. We'll wait for the plane,'' you tell the others. ``Bill probably ran into bad weather. Anything can happen up there.''[/p] [p]Mimla nods. She looks calm and ready for anything. But Haven, who's sitting in a corner of the barn, looks ready to jump out of his skin. He keeps pulling sheets of computer programs out of his pocket, fumbling through them, and then stuffing them back into his pocket.[/p] [p]You sit down in a comfortable spot in the hay. The sun is shining through a window onto your lap. It feels good. You watch Haven go through his ritual. ``There's something strange about him,'' you think. Haven looks up from his papers and flashes you a nervous grin, then goes back to his sorting. You close your eyes, lean back, and relax.[/p] [p]The next thing you know, Matt is gently shaking you awake. ``Time to go. The plane is coming in.''[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="14"][/p] [p]``All right. The truck it is, Matt,'' you say.[/p] [p]``Then let's go!''[/p] [p]You give one last look at Bill, the pilot You'd like to take him along – he's been a good friend – but it's more important that Mimla, Matt, Haven, and you get away.[/p] [p]Matt left the cockpit with Mimla and Haven. You grab your kit and start to leave the Windmaster, but suddenly you have a thought. Quickly you raid the plane's lockers, throwing everything that might be useful out the door: first-aid kit, blankets, rope, food, and last, the submachine gun stashed under the pilot's seat. You jump out of the plane. Matt has seen the things flying out of the door. He drives the truck to the Windmaster's side and rapidly stows the supplies.[/p] [p]It seems to take forever, but in two minutes you're all loaded into the truck, a 2005 Chevy Blazer four-wheel drive – old, but serviceable. You head north, toward Turtalia.[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="16"][/p] [p]When the plane is stable, you feel an incredible rush of relief, though you are also pale and almost queasy. Matt notices instantly.[/p] [p]``Hey, relax. You did it! I'll take the controls for a while. I can handle it, and you could use a little rest.''[/p] [p]Gratefully you take your hands from the control stick. You'll be all right in a minute or two.[/p] [p]``Those [em]were[/em] Doradan troops out there,'' Matt says as you slump back in your seat. ``I saw them as we climbed out of there. It's a good thing we left.''[/p]

[p]``It sure is,'' you say, straightening up a bit. You feel much better already. ``I wonder what we should do now.''[/p] [p]``What do you mean? I thought we were flying out of here.''[/p] [p]``We are, but maybe we should circle here for a while first. I'm also not sure if we should head directly for Denver. These clouds around us reminded me of the violent weather in these mountains.'' You are sitting up straight now. Talking has helped you a lot. ``Flying in these mountains, and in what could be bad weather, is no picnic.''[/p] [p]``I get your point,'' Matt says. ``But we've got a lot to lose, and we really have to try to get Bill to a doctor. I think we should head to Denver now.''[/p]
p.next: If you decide to follow Matt's instincts and fly straight to Denver
If you decide to follow your instincts and circle while you examine the possibilities

p.text: [p]``Better get off the road,'' Matt suggests. ``Keep to the scrub – there'll be less dust that way. Maybe they'll be so busy with the plane they won't notice us.''[/p] [p]Soon you're out of sight of the barn and the forlorn-looking Windmaster. The column of dust from the Doradan troops, if that's who it really is – you certainly couldn't stick around to find out – is much closer.[/p] [p]``I took a good look before we disappeared over that rise,'' Matt says. ``I think they'll be at the plane in about ten minutes.''[/p] [p]Matt is interrupted by a low BA-DOOM!![/p] [p]``Bazooka-launched rocket,'' you say. ``It must be the Doradan Secret Police.'' You shudder at the thought.[/p]

[p]``Mimla's right,'' you say. ``Our chances are much better if we separate. She and I will head for Santa Fe. I know of a 'safe house' there. We can meet in two days. OK, Matt?''[/p] [p]``I don't like it. I'm responsible for Mimla, and the four of us would all be better off together if there was a fight.''[/p] [p]But Mimla is firm, and so are you. Matt finally agrees. Haven remains quiet; he looks scared.[/p] [p]``Here, Matt. This is the location of the 'safe house.''' You show it to him on a map of downtown Santa Fe. The ``safe house'' is just two blocks west of the main plaza.[/p] [p]You all shake hands and prepare to leave. At that very moment there is a knock at the door – a loud knock![/p]
p.next: If you decide to run for it through the back door of the house
If you decide to wait where you are and prepare to defend yourselves

p.text: [p]You agree with Matt. If the four of you split up, your chances are no better. You need the protection of the group; it just makes good sense to have more eyes and ears.[/p] [p]Matt is already busy with a map, plotting an escape route through the Sangre de Cristo Mountains to Denver.[/p] [p]``It's going to be a long haul. A very long haul,'' he says.[/p] [p]``Well, at least there's that 'safe house' in Santa Fe that I was told about,'' you say. ``We can stop there before we go into the mountains.''[/p] [p]You and Mimla examine the map along with Matt Haven sits quietly, absorbed in thoughts he shares with no one.[/p] [p]Mimla suggests avoiding the mountains by going east, heading to Denver by the flatland route.[/p] [p]``Mim, that's dangerous. I mean really dangerous!'' you exclaim. ``Out there in the flats we'd be sitting ducks from the air.''[/p] [p]She nods agreement. ``That's exactly it. The Doradans will expect us to head into the mountains. They'd never think we'd make plans for the flats. But let's not argue. Let's decide and get going.''[/p]
p.next: If you decide to take the mountain route with the first stop in Santa Fe
If you decide to take the flatland route

p.text: [p]``Matt, I want to circle here a bit. Let's get used to the plane and watch the weather for a while.''[/p] [p]``OK,'' he agrees. ``But just for a little while.''[/p] [p]The plane feels good in your hands. It responds well to your commands, and soon you almost forget you're not really a pilot You are bothered by the weather, though. The clouds keep building and look more and more nasty.[/p] [p]``Matt, I'm worried about this weather.''[/p] [p]``How so?''[/p] [p]``It looks as if we'll have to fly by instruments. We won't be able to see once we're in those clouds. It also looks as if they have violent winds in them. That could be really bad. And then there's the chance of hail, and the plane icing up...''[/p] [p]``You make it sound impossible!'' says Matt.[/p] [p]``It's not impossible. Just not good.''[/p] [p]``What other choice do we have?''[/p] [p]``We could go back.''[/p] [p]``[em]No way[/em],'' you hear Mimla shout[/p] [p]``I agree,'' Matt says. ``It could be death for Mimla. It could be death for us all.''[/p]

[p]Then you have a thought. ``I wonder if we can get a weather forecast from Dorado.''[/p] [p]``But we break radio silence that way,'' Matt says. ``They could home in on us and blow us out of the sky.'' Haven looks uneasy at this prospect, and you're not too happy about it either.[/p] [p]``Still,'' you say, ``it would give us some information. I think I can make up a fake message that won't give us away.''[/p]
p.next: If you decide to break radio silence and try to get a weather forecast
If you decide to maintain silence and see if you can come up with another idea

p.text: [p]Time is too precious for you to waste it flying in circles. You must get the Doradan invasion plans to Turtalia! You have to get over the mountains and on to Denver. There is no other way for you, and Mimla strongly agrees with Matt. She wants to continue the fight against Doradan brutality at any risk.[/p] [p]The cumulus clouds tower about you, and the plane is bouncing around in the turbulence. You crane your neck, scanning the sky for some break in the clouds below you.[/p] [p]It's a tough decision. Should you descend through the clouds in search of clearer airspace and face the danger of crashing into a mountain peak? Or should you climb higher to get over the clouds and face the danger of running into even more turbulence?[/p]
p.next: If you descend
If you climb

p.text: [p class="inlineImage" data-img="24"][/p] [p]The plane noses down into a dive again, then starts spinning wildly. The spin throws Haven off balance. He goes crashing to one side of the cockpit, dazed. You grab for the controls. The Windmaster levels off. Matt comes running forward with the rope, with Mimla close behind him.[/p] [p]``What happened?'' Matt yells.[/p] [p]``Tie him up. Quickly.'' You're busy trying to gain altitude.[/p] [p]Just as Matt gets near him, Haven screams and starts flailing his arms. Matt and Mimla can't get close enough to subdue him. Haven seems berserk; he is wildly hitting the control panel, knocking at switches and dials.[/p] [p]``Stop him!''[/p] [p]Too late! Haven hit the transmit switch on the transponder. The plane is now broadcasting a signal that reports its location. Doradan pursuit planes are probably homing in on you right now.[/p]

[p]Matt gets in a punch and Haven goes down. Matt and Mimla truss him up like a chicken in a matter of seconds. He should be no more trouble now.[/p] [p]Just as Haven is knocked down you reach for the transponder to turn it off, but instead you pull your hand away again. The Doradans would think it very strange if your transponder suddenly went off the air.[/p] [p]Your father has taught you some Doradan codes. You could try to fake it by inventing a false ID and secret mission. Or you could turn off the transponder as you first planned and try to hide in the clouds.[/p]
p.next: If you flick off the transponder and head for the clouds
If you try to fake it, pick up the mike

p.text: [p]Taos it is. It's near the Turtalian-Doradan border, and you want to get out of this turbulence. You do a rough calculation based on your last-known position, your airspeed, the wind speed and direction, and your own gut feeling of where you are. You figure that you're probably right over Taos at this very moment.[/p] [p]According to the last reports, the Taos regime has remained independent. Taos is free of Doradan control except for an occasional military patrol to prevent the Pueblos from becoming actively hostile to the Doradans. Mimla will be safe there.[/p] [p]You feel good about this decision, and you slip through the clouds until the outline of mountains and valley and desert floor appear below you. The landing is tricky but possible. Deep in your memory is all the flight instruction you had from your father: ``[em]Set up your approach. Don't drop your airspeed too rapidly or you'll stall. Don't be low and slow. Flare at the right time to spill air, and create a planned stall just as you touch down.[/em]''[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="29"][/p] [p]It looks rough above, but you'd rather face turbulence than the terror of hitting some cloudcovered mountain peak. The Windmaster responds nicely to your control movements, making a spiraling climb through the cloud whiteness. For several moments you enjoy the sheer pleasure of flying, remembering calmer days when your dad sat behind you in a sleek, orange Swiss-built sailplane teaching you the freedom of flight.[/p] [p]Suddenly you top out above the clouds in bright sunlight that immediately warms the cabin.[/p] [p]``Not bad! Boy, I hope the whole flight is like this,'' Matt exclaims.[/p] [p]``Well, let's just hope that we can get back down through these clouds when we reach Denver. That's when Bill would have helped the most.''[/p] [p]Mimla has been quiet, but she suddenly speaks.[/p] [p]``Look! Look!''[/p] [p]She points to the two o'clock position. You can see three patrol planes out the window. Sunlight glints off the bright green and blue markings of Dorado emblazoned on their wings.[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="30"][/p] [p]Mimla raises a finger to her lips at the sound of the knock. Haven cringes in the corner as if he's trying to look like a piece of furniture. You, Matt, and Mimla load the weapons Julio has hidden in his house – old M-16s left over from territorial wars and colonial conflicts of the 1980s and '90s. You push the selector lever to automatic fire.[/p] [p]Once again the knock reverberates through the house. Then you hear a faint voice.[/p] [p]``[em]Amigos. Mis amigos[/em], do not be afraid. It is me, Julio. Open... open, please.''[/p] [p]You glance at your watch. It is almost five o'clock, a dangerous hour: the Doradan rulers have set a five o'clock curfew for the last three years. Anyone seen on the street between five P.M. and six A.M. can be shot on sight To the Doradan troopers of the Elite Squad, shooting people out on the streets is a game.[/p] [p]``[em]Amigos[/em], let me in, please.''[/p] [p]Julio hasn't used the code knock – three short, one long, two short. Your watch reads 4:58.[/p]
p.next: If you open the door
If you ask for the special knock

p.text: [p]You pick up the microphone. ``Calling any Turtalian base. Repeat, any Turtalian base. We are in trouble. Need help in landing our plane. The pilot is unconscious, perhaps dead. Repeat, SOS. Anybody out there?''[/p] [p]For several tense moments you strain your ears, waiting for a response. Then it comes.[/p] [p]``Turtalian advance base to aircraft in trouble. Head out on a course of forty degrees northeast, altitude fourteen thousand feet. Air speed of one hundred knots. We will pick you up and guide you home.''[/p] [p]Matt slaps you on the back. ``Sounds good. We'll make it!''[/p] [p]Then the radio comes to life again.[/p] [p]``Windmaster in trouble. We read you. This is a Turtalian base. We will send escort craft to pick you up and guide you in. Maintain present altitude, circle, and leave your transponder on. Help is on the way.''[/p] [p]``Well, there we are,'' Matt says. ``Two answers. Which one is real? One of them has to be the Doradans.''[/p]
p.next: If you follow the first set of instructions
If you follow the second set

p.text: [p]You're sure you can break radio silence and not be recognized. As you pick up the mike to radio for a weather forecast, Haven becomes hysterical.[/p] [p]``[em]We're all going to die![/em]'' he shrieks. He repeats it, calmly this time, almost in a monotone: ``We're – all – going – to – die.''[/p] [p]Then he lunges for the controls![/p] [p]The Windmaster starts to dive as you try to fend him off. Matt and Mimla grab Haven and pull him away. He shakes them off and then crouches in a corner of the cabin near Bill's unconscious form. Haven is breathing rapidly; his eyes are glazed. You pull the plane out of its dive just in time.[/p] [p]``What do we do now?'' Matt asks in a low voice, jerking his head toward Haven.[/p] [p]You give Haven a quick glance.[/p] [p]He looks better. His breathing is quieter and less labored, and there is some color coming back into his cheeks. But you suspect he could blow again at any moment. You decide you'd better tie Haven up.[/p] [p]You signal Matt, and he goes off to get some rope. Without warning, Haven jumps for the controls again. You try to knock him away, but his craziness seems to give him superhuman strength. He is winning![/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="34"][/p] [p]You argue strongly for the mountain route. Your argument that there will be friendly guerrilla groups and partisans in the hills is what wins the decision. Now it's up to you to lead the escape.[/p] [p]``We haven't got much time. The patrols will be all over now that they have our escape plane down. They'll search the area around the airstrip and north of there. We'll actually be behind them – that is, unless they figure out that we came back into town.''[/p] [p]You keep an eye on the building across the street. There is a lot of activity – jeeps, jitneys, and an occasional staff car coming and going. Then you see them: two men in their early sixties. One is grotesquely fat, with triple chins and bulging eyes. Diamond rings punctuate his stubby fingers.[/p] [p]The other man is trim and short, dressed in a well-tailored uniform without insignia of any kind. You recognize him. He's the head of the Doradan Secret Police, and he is walking across the street toward your hideout![/p]

[p]The landing strip at Taos is too risky, you argue. Matt finally agrees that you should avoid it. You still haven't solved your problems, however: the turbulence in the clouds you're flying through could rip a wing off the Windmaster.[/p] [p]``Hey, Matt,'' you say. ``What's your guess on how far it is to the West Coast?''[/p] [p]Matt pores over the charts. Haven peers up from his doodling. He looks anxious, as usual. ``California is not safe. I know it is not a safe place.''[/p] [p]You and Matt exchange glances. He answers, ``I don't agree. California isn't controlled by any group. We stand as good a chance of making it there as anywhere.''[/p] [p]You nod agreement. Mimla disagrees. She grips Matt by the arm and says, ``I have reason to believe that Haven is right California isn't safe. Let's put the plane down here in Taos.''[/p] [p]Matt is uncomfortable. After all, he was entrusted to accompany Mimla and help her escape to Turtalia.[/p]

[p]You're not sure you can handle the motorglider in turbulence. You push the control column forward, sending the Windmaster into a steep dive through the clouds. You kick the rudder pedals hard and sideslip down to thirteen thousand feet before leveling off.[/p] [p]You're in luck. The cloud cover ends abruptly, and at last you have enough visibility and room to fly in. Mountains surround you, and you weave around them. The air currents are tricky; the rock faces and tree-covered slopes seem too close for comfort[/p] [p]``Any suggestions, Matt?'' you ask. ``I haven't the faintest idea where we are.''[/p] [p]Matt shakes his head.[/p] [p]``No, we're up against it. We could radio to the Turtalians for help.''[/p] [p]``Yes, but that's dangerous. The Doradans could beam in on us, and then it's all over.''[/p]
p.next: If you radio for Turtalian help
If you continue on, using your intuition

p.text: [p]The sound of the explosion finally stops echoing in the hills. ``Well, they must have gotten the plane as soon as they could see it,'' Matt says after a pause.[/p] [p]``I wonder if they've seen us?'' you ask nobody in particular.[/p] [p]``No way of telling,'' Matt answers. He glances around the truck. Mimla looks alert and ready to do whatever is necessary. Haven looks so pale that he might pass out at any time.[/p] [p]``We have to decide what to do.''[/p] [p]``And with no information,'' Mimla adds. ``I wish we knew if they'd spotted us, or assumed we were in the plane, or if they've called in search planes, or...''[/p] [p]``Wait a minute, hold on,'' you say. ``It doesn't make any difference. We have to get out of here, no matter what. We have two ways to travel now: in the Blazer or on foot The Blazer is faster, but it's easier for them to spot. Walking is slower, but it's easier for us to hide.'' You bang the steering wheel with your hands. ``I wish I knew which one to choose.''[/p] [p]``Got a coin?'' Matt asks with a smile.[/p]
p.next: If you decide to abandon the Blazer and head out on foot
If you decide to keep going in the Blazer

p.text: [p]You realize that a fake radio message is just the sort of slipup the secret police are on the lookout for now, and you decide to keep radio silence. This is dangerous, because you really need as much help as you can get with this plane. The air has gotten bumpy, and flying takes all your concentration.[/p] [p]Matt has found a map case with a sectional flight map of the region you're in.[/p] [p]``Look at this!'' he cries. ``There's an emergency strip just a little north of Taos. Let's head for it.''[/p] [p]You take a quick glance, just enough to see that the strip is nestled in the region close to Kachina Peak. It could be tough making that approach in clouds. One big mistake and WHAMMO![/p]
p.next: If you decide to land at the abandoned strip in Taos
If you decide to keep on flying in the general direction of Denver

p.text: [p class="inlineImage" data-img="40"][/p] [p]``Let's get out of here. Come on, Mimla,'' you whisper.[/p] [p]You all dash for the back door. Matt gets to it first and opens it. He sticks his head out, then whispers:[/p] [p]``All clear. Come on.''[/p] [p]The door leads out onto a back alley that winds through a maze of streets and behind stores, of fice buildings, and a few large apartment buildings. As you enter the alley you realize Haven isn't with you.[/p] [p]``Hey, where's Haven?'' You look around. Mimla and Matt shake their heads.[/p] [p]``We can't leave him.''[/p] [p]Matt looks disgusted. ``Don't bother looking for him. We can't waste the time. He'll have to fend for himself. Let's go.''[/p]
p.next: If you go back to look for Haven
If you go on and leave Haven behind

p.text: [p]The flatland route seems best, but Albuquerque's curfew has begun, and you must wait until morning to start. The night passes very slowly, punctuated by the occasional sounds of gunfire. Finally dawn spreads across the eastern sky.[/p] [p]The curfew ends at six A.M. Your plan is to leave immediately, disguised as Doradan militia ready for your weekly training. In Dorado all the citizens must serve in the militia, although only regular military have weapons. The training takes place each day, and the day of your training is assigned by lottery. ID cards are issued to all Doradans – complete with physical description, date of birth, and a number, from one to seven, indicating your training day.[/p] [p]Julio has a stock of militia uniforms, and he has been busy most of the night preparing your ID cards, all with the number four in the upper right It is not easy work. The Doradans will shoot first and ask questions later if they suspect the IDs are phony ones.[/p] [p]``All set?'' Matt asks. ``We'll go singly to the square and then group up and take a jitney as though we were heading for a training site.''[/p]

[p]``Let's get going on foot,'' you say. ``It's slower, but safer.''[/p] [p]You turn the Blazer down a gully and park it under an overhang. It's well hidden there.[/p] [p]Quickly the four of you gather everything useful out of the truck and start to make manageable bundles out of it. Matt grabs the submachine gun. ``I'm a first-class marksman,'' he says without bragging.[/p] [p]``Let's hope it won't come to that.''[/p] [p]You finish tucking your gear into your makeshift pack and stand up. Matt is almost done with his, and you turn to check how Mimla and Haven are doing.[/p] [p]Mimla is nearly finished as well, but you don't see Haven.[/p] [p]You turn around in a circle. ``Matt, where's Haven?'' you ask.[/p] [p]Matt lifts his head. ``Dunno. He was here a minute ago. Maybe he's in the bushes.''[/p] [p]The three of you search for several minutes, but you don't find Haven.[/p]

[p]Haven struggles against Matt, but he is too weak. Matt searches him and finds a Doradan Secret Police ID card hidden in his clothing.[/p] [p]At six P.M. sharp there is a tap on the back door. You open it There is no time to delay now. The head of the secret police motions to a government limousine pulled up to the door. You all get in, putting Haven – tied and gagged – in the trunk, and he drives you off into the night to a fuel supply depot on the outskirts of town. There you, Mimla, and Matt are hidden in a special section of a sixteen-wheel oil tanker – and you're off for Santa Fe, the mountains, and Denver.[/p] [p]Haven has been taken away by two men in blue coveralls. He will be jailed.[/p] [p]The adventure is over, for now.[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p]You are so frightened that you can't even speak. You motion to the others to be quiet The fat man gets into a car and roars off, leaving a cloud of fumes behind.[/p] [p]The other man walks directly to the door of Julio's house. He stops, pulls out a cigarette, lights it, and drops the pack in front of the door. He examines the door as if looking at an art work in a museum and stoops to tie his shoelace – which is already tied. Then he speaks in a voice that's almost a whisper.[/p] [p]``Read the message in the cigarette pack. NAMASTE!''[/p] [p]You almost collapse from fear and surprise. [em]Namaste[/em] is the Turtalian code word given to you by your father to identify agents. No one knows it but you and top-secret Turtalian agents in Dorado.[/p] [p]Can you trust the head of the secret police? Is he really an agent of Turtalia – or did he get the code word [em]Namaste[/em] by torturing one of your people?[/p]
p.next: If you decide to trust him and open the door to pick up the cigarette pack
If not

p.text: [p class="inlineImage" data-img="46"][/p] [p]``He must have run away,'' Matt says.[/p] [p]``But why?'' you and Mimla ask together.[/p] [p]``Scared, maybe? People do funny things when they're frightened.''[/p] [p]``Well, what do we do now? We need those computer codes he's got Do we look for him or leave him?'' Your question hangs in the dry desert air.[/p]
p.next: If you decide to abandon Haven
If you search for Haven

p.text: [p]``Wow! Where did they come from? How did they know we were here?'' Matt scans the sky with binoculars. ``Those are prop planes.''[/p] [p]They're not very fast, but they're fast enough. ``What do you think, Matt – Mimla? Have they seen us?'' you ask.[/p] [p]``No, not yet, but they will at any moment,'' Matt answers. ``What are our chances if we run for it?''[/p] [p]You estimate that your distance from the patrol planes is a little over six miles. You are hovering right above the cloud cover. The wind is with you, and with engines at full-throttle, you could reach an airspeed of 150 knots.[/p] [p]If you run for it, you could cross into Turtalian airspace, but the patrol planes will probably follow anyway. If you duck back into the clouds, they will just circle around until you come out again.[/p]
p.next: If you decide to run for it
If you duck back into the clouds

p.text: [p]``Look, if we stay with the Blazer we can get farther away,'' says Mimla. ``They probably won't spot us before we spot them. If they do, we can leave the truck then.''[/p] [p]``Good thinking, Mimla. Matt, check out those maps in the glove compartment, and find the best route. Haven, keep an eye out for the Doradans.'' Then you have second thoughts. ``Mimla, you keep a lookout, too.''[/p] [p]You concentrate on driving. It's tough work. You have to detour around the large trees and the cacti, and keep your speed up. At the same time, you're looking in the rearview mirror, watching the dust cloud the truck kicks up and trying to keep it as small as possible. The dust cloud is what could draw the attention of the Doradan Secret Police – unless they spot the truck from the air.[/p] [p]Matt keeps looking up from the maps spread on his knees to check his bearings and the lay of the land.[/p] [p]``We're pretty exposed where we are,'' he says finally. ``There's not much in the way of hiding places. To the northwest the terrain gets a little better, but it's not the direction we want to go – [em]that[/em] direction is blocked by the Continental Divide.''[/p] [p]``What about going over the divide?'' you ask.[/p] [p]``There's only one pass that's close. How's this for a name: Satan Pass?''[/p]

[p]``Sounds grisly,'' you answer.[/p] [p]``The road's probably in grisly shape, too. We could also stay west of the divide and drive parallel to it. The only trouble is we'd be exposed on the road.''[/p] [p]``Is that Highway fifty-six?'' You've been sneaking glances at the maps.[/p] [p]``Yes.''[/p] [p]``Wait a minute,'' Mimla says. ``So far we have no reason to think that the secret police know we're here or that we're driving a Blazer. If we take the highway we'll just look like an ordinary truck. And we can have three pairs of eyes on the lookout.''[/p] [p]``Sounds OK, Mimla,'' you respond, ``but there's good cover up in Satan Pass; we'd be hard to spot there. It also won't seem like the direction that we'd choose to go in – and if the police are looking for us, they probably won't check it out.''[/p]
p.next: If you decide to head over Satan Pass
If you decide to stay west of the divide and try Highway 56

p.text: [p]``That's it. Back into the clouds. No way can we outrun those planes.''[/p] [p]The Windmaster bumps several times in the turbulence. Then you are hidden by the white cloud vapor.[/p] [p]The radio comes to life.[/p] [p]``This is Turtalian Free Land radio base. We have you on our radar. Identify yourself with proper code.''[/p] [p]Safety! But only if you use the proper codes. You find the identification codes in a small canvas pouch along with the flight maps and charts. They are to be used only in emergencies. Surely this is one.[/p]

[p]Using the radio would be too risky. You continue to navigate by instinct Once again you enter the cloud cover, circle briefly until you spot another opening, and descend into clear space. And once again luck is with you; the area is relatively open.[/p] [p]``Look! Look to the left. See? Down there! It looks like a landing strip,'' cries Mimla. ``I think you're right, Mimla. Good eyes. Let's try it!''[/p] [p]Your heart thumping and your hands clammy on the wheel, you descend toward the isolated emergency landing strip.[/p]

[p]You pick up the microphone and begin broadcasting to the Doradans.[/p] [p]``Gallup Base. This is mission Y-niner. We are initiating phase number three. Over.''[/p] [p]Matt looks questioningly at you. You'd like to explain what you're doing, but you can't take the time right now. You are thinking furiously and waiting for a Doradan response to your transmission. You wave Matt to be quiet.[/p] [p]``Y-niner. This is Gallup Base. Who the devil are you? Over.''[/p] [p]``Gallup Base. Code One, please. Repeat, Code One. Authorization zebra-delta-baker-five. Over.''[/p] [p]There is a light film of sweat on your forehead. If your father's code information is correct, you have told Gallup Base you are in the middle of a secret reconnaissance mission with the highest of Doradan security priorities. Right now there should be a mad scramble at Gallup Base while codes are being checked and... there is a crackle from the radio:[/p] [p]``Y-niner. Please stand by. Over.''[/p] [p]``Uh-oh,'' you think. Either you've blown the code or the Doradans are so disorganized that they need time to figure it out.[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="53"][/p] [p]``OK, we'1l run for it. Those three planes will never get us.'' You hope you're right.[/p] [p]You open the throttles wide and head for Denver.[/p] [p]Suddenly, right ahead of you, there is one more plane bearing the green and blue Doradan squares. Your Windmaster is wreathed in a halo of tracer bullets. Your last thought is, ``Why can't the world be peaceful?''[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p]Clutching your phony IDs, the four of you line up at Julio's back door. You'll be leaving at fourminute intervals.[/p] [p]You wish your companions good luck. Matt walks out first – strong, tough-looking, confident. He scowls a little to complete the picture of a loyal Doradan militiaman who hopes to make it into the full-time military – a highly-paid elite group with special privileges and rights.[/p] [p]Next is Mimla, who has been waiting calmly. She too walks out confidently, turns the corner at the end of the alley, and disappears. Now it's Haven's turn. He hesitates, fidgeting with the sand-colored gun belt around his waist.[/p] [p]``I can't do it. They'll catch me. I can't do it!''[/p] [p]You grab him by the arm and push him through the door.[/p] [p]``Yes, you can. I'm with you.''[/p] [p]You almost have to support him as the two of you move down the dark alley toward the corner that will put you right in front of Doradan Secret Police Headquarters. You don't like this one bit Haven is trembling, ashen-faced, and unsteady on his feet He could break at any moment Just one look from some tough Doradan and it might be all over.[/p]

[p]In this kind of game, it's each for himself. You can't go back to look for Haven. You're carrying the plans of the Doradan invasion; Mimla's the head of the resistance. The stakes are bigger than one person.[/p] [p]You give a last look back at the open doorway. Then you, Matt, and Mimla dash down the alley and make for the first open door in the seventeen-story apartment building opposite. You run in and find yourselves in a parking garage. Matt locks the door. The cement floor is dry and gritty under your shoes. You feel as if the whole world can hear every step you take.[/p] [p]There are about twenty cars in the garage. The parking attendant is an old man who is dozing in a cubicle. His TV set is on – tuned to the only station, Doradan government TV – and the sound covers your approach. You have no trouble overcoming him and tying him up. He smiles weakly at you and flashes the victory sign as you grab a set of keys from a rack over his head Minutes later you, Mimla, and Matt are in a twodoor, silver-colored Japanese sedan. It's an old car but still in good shape.[/p] [p]You pull out of the garage and head north toward Santa Fe and freedom.[/p] [p]``We'd be home tonight,'' you say, and you know you're right.[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="56"][/p] [p]You take a chance on it really being Julio.[/p] [p]``Cover me, Matt. I'll open the door on three.''[/p] [p]You edge up to the door and count in a voice just loud enough for the others in the room to hear you:[/p] [p]``[em]One... two... three[/em] .''[/p] [p]On [em]three[/em] you shove the heavy wooden door forward. It groans on its iron hinges. A bolt of late afternoon sun pierces the semigloom of the room. Julio slips in and slams the door behind him. He leans against the door grinning at the four of you.[/p] [p]``Sorry, but I didn't have much time. Those monkeys in the uniforms shoot poorly, but with my luck, who knows?''[/p] [p]``OK, OK, Julio. What news have you brought us?'' you ask.[/p] [p]Julio twists his hat in his hands, a somber expression on his face. You know before he speaks that the news is bad.[/p] [p]``Senorita Mimla, it is with the greatest sadness that I must inform you of the capture of your two cousins.''[/p] [p]Julio nods in the direction of the secret police headquarters across the street Mimla shudders. Matt goes to her and grips her hand.[/p] [p]``Those men were our best, our very best,'' Mimla gasps. ``How did they get them? There must be an informer. First they got Matt and me, now my cousins!''[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="58"][/p] [p]It seems to be taking the Doradans forever to respond. You turn to Matt.[/p] [p]``Did you know you're flying with your fingers crossed?'' he asks.[/p] [p]``Yes, and I'm keeping them that way.'' You fill Matt in on what you're doing.[/p] [p]``I hope it works. What do we do if it doesn't?''[/p] [p]``I don't know,'' you answer. ``I don't know.''[/p] [p]The radio crackles. ``Y-niner. This is Gallup Base. Change heading to one-one-seven. Repeat, one-one-seven. Authorization override baker-five. Do you copy?''[/p] [p]``What does that mean?'' Matt asks.[/p] [p]``Not sure. They want us to change our course, but the code and authorization I gave them for our mission should have had such priority that they couldn't do that.''[/p] [p]``What's 'authorization override baker-five'?''[/p] [p]``That's what worries me. I've never heard of it. It leaves two possibilities. One: it's a real code and Turtalian intelligence doesn't know about it. Two: it's as fake as our ID and [em]they[/em] know it but hope [em]we[/em] don't.''[/p] [p]``What do we do?'' says Matt.[/p] [p]``Good question. Either we change heading, the way they told us to, and keep on faking it – or we run for it. There are no chase planes in sight. We might make it.''[/p] [p]The radio crackles again.[/p] [p]``Y-niner. Do you copy course change?''[/p]
p.next: If you decide to change your heading
If you run for it

p.text: [p]``It's worth a try. I'm going to open the door,'' you say.[/p] [p]You move to the door. Just as you reach for the latch, Haven leaps across the room and grabs you.[/p] [p]``No, no! Don't! It's a trick. It's a trick. We'll all be killed.''[/p] [p]You look at Haven, then Mimla, and finally at Matt. Haven is shaking, holding on to your arm. ``Please don't, I'll find a way out for us. I'll find a way out.''[/p] [p]Haven's words surprise everyone. He has always been so quiet.[/p] [p]Outside the light is growing dimmer. Soon it will be time for curfew.[/p]
p.next: If you open the door to retrieve the cigarette pack
If you follow Haven's advice and ignore the message from the Doradan Secret Police chief

p.text: [p class="inlineImage" data-img="61"][/p] [p]You all agree that there is something suspicious about the unguarded jeep. You head off on foot into the flatland. The sun climbs high into the sky, and the arid land shimmers. There are days of long, hard walking ahead. It will probably be better to travel at night.[/p] [p]Good luck![/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p]``Gallup Base, this is Y-niner. We copy and are changing course to one-one-seven.''[/p] [p]You kick the rudder pedals and bring the control column over to the right. The numbers on the compass flash by: 80-90-100-110. You start to level off and steady in on your new course of 117 degrees.[/p] [p]``I don't like this,'' Matt says. ``I feel uneasy. Can we do anything else?''[/p] [p]``Not now,'' you sigh as you point to the Doradan chase planes flanking you.[/p] [p]The fighter planes escort you to a small Doradan military airfield.[/p] [p]Once or twice en route you think you spy a good escape route, but you don't try it. The fighter planes carry heat-seeking missiles that are capable of blowing you to bits.[/p] [p]When you land, Bill is taken away in an ambulance. You are arrested and taken away for trial – in a year or two – as escapees from glorious ``totalitarian freedom.''[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p]Run for it! It seems like the best thing to do. You flick off the transponder but leave the radio on.[/p] [p]The sky is filled with clouds, and there is an especially large one near your plane. The radio crackles on.[/p] [p]``Y-niner. Come in, Y-niner. This is Gallup Base. Code nine. Code nine. Come in, Y-niner. This is Gallup Base. Sir, they're not... '' The radio cuts out. You're surrounded by silence and the white cloud.[/p] [p]``There should be planes here any minute. Let's hope they don't find us.''[/p] [p]Then you have an idea! You have been watching the variometer since you entered the cloud. The instrument has shown large masses of steadily rising air. Quickly you start flying the Windmaster in a tight circle and turn the engines off.[/p] [p]``What? Are you crazy?'' Matt yells.[/p] [p]``Hang on. Calm down. This plane has a glide ratio of twenty to one. I don't know if we can climb, but we should be able to maintain our altitude. The wind will cool off the exhausts in a few minutes. They won't find us unless they blunder right into us.''[/p] [p]``I hope you're right,'' Matt says in a doubtful tone.[/p] [p]``Me, too.''[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="64"][/p] [p]You [em]are[/em] right The Windmaster is holding her altitude, perhaps even climbing a few feet every turn. With your eye on the instruments, you start flipping the radio through the broadcast bands.[/p] [p]``Search Leader to base, negative sighting.''[/p] [p]``That's them!'' you whisper to Matt. You're not sure why you're whispering. They couldn't hear you even if you opened a window and shouted at the top of your lungs.[/p] [p]``Base to Search Leader, continue search.''[/p] [p]``Search Leader to Search One, check that cloud.''[/p] [p]You turn to Matt and hold up one hand; your fingers are crossed. Matt holds up [em]both[/em] his hands with a grin; [em]all[/em] his fingers are crossed.[/p] [p]A couple of minutes pass, then:[/p] [p]``Search One to Search Leader, negative. Wait! I've got them sighted, just below me!''[/p] [p]You gulp hard and frantically search the sky. The cloud has thinned out a bit above you, and you catch a glimpse of a Doradan fighter. Then the cloud thickens again.[/p] [p]``Search Leader to Search One. Climb hard. Missile away. Fire!''[/p]

[p]You wish this landing were just a practice one with your dad. But this one is all yours, and it's for real.[/p] [p]Just as quickly as the clouds break up they come back. You start to panic as you approach the airstrip.[/p] [p]Hold on. Bank. Kick the starboard pedal. Push the stick slightly forward and move it to the starboard. Ease in more power. Watch the altimeter! Careful! Careful![/p] [p]The clouds break. You are just south of the strip, about 1,000 feet above it. You go into the final approach, release flaps, and keep your airspeed near 100 knots.[/p] [p]Touchdown! The rubber tires squeak, then roll on the bumpy surface.[/p] [p][em]Perfect landing.[/em][/p] [p]The Pueblo Indians in the area welcome you. They give you shelter and food and take care of the sick pilot. In the spring, when the snowpack melts, you will cross the mountain passes on your way to Denver.[/p] [p]Well done. Congratulations![/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p]You override Mimla's desire to put down in Taos. After all, you're the pilot and in command. This time your decision remains firm, and the Windmaster heads west. You have enough gas for your estimated time of arrival into the Los Angeles area, and the weather improves after just forty minutes of flying away from Taos.[/p] [p]``Not bad! We'll make it OK.'' You sound cheerful and encouraging, but no one else in the plane is smiling. Mimla looks furious, Haven keeps doodling, and Matt stares out at the skyline. ``Turn up the radio, will you, Matt? We're getting something.''[/p] [p]Matt fiddles with the tuning and volume dials. There is the usual snap and pop. Then the signal becomes clear – too clear. It is a string of battle commands from ground troops and helicopter strike-forces. There seem to be well-armed gangs, probably former soldiers, operating in the entire Los Angeles area.[/p] [p]You'll reach the L.A. zone in less than an hour. Maybe it's the wrong place to land. Perhaps you should head north toward what's left of San Francisco. It is supposedly devastated by fire and bombing, but it might still be safer.[/p]
p.next: If you go on toward Los Angeles
If you head north toward San Francisco

p.text: [p]``I'm not leaving,'' you say firmly. ``First of all, [em]someone[/em] has to take care of Bill; second, it's nonsense to leave. We have a better chance to be found here than if we are wandering around like jackrabbits in the wilderness. You go if you want.''[/p] [p]Mimla sneers at you, and Matt shrugs his shoulders. ``Well, I'm with her – but you're probably right Good luck. Godspeed.''[/p] [p]Haven joins them. The three of them start off, and soon they're lost to sight.[/p] [p]You build a fire from dried pinon branches. The smoke smells good. At the end of the second day, Bill suddenly trembles convulsively and then lies back, quiet. He is dead.[/p] [p]You run out of food. The days merge into each other. Hallucinations of friends, warm sunny beaches, and sumptuous meals fill your waking hours. You drift in soft waves of warmth and cold. One afternoon you hear voices, but you're sure they're only more hallucinations.[/p] [p]They are not! It is a Turtalian rescue party. You are saved.[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p]The first set of instructions gave a 40° NE compass heading, which is about right for the Denver area. Besides that, the second set identified you as a Windmaster. Only the Doradans are searching for your Windmaster; the Turtalians at central command are keeping the mission a secret. A Turtalian base receiving your message wouldn't know what aircraft you were in.[/p] [p]You swing out on the 40° NE heading, climb to 14,000 feet, and head homeward. Constant guidance from the Turtalian base brings you safely over the mountains. Occasionally you see the peaks of the Rockies sticking through the gauzy clouds.[/p] [p]Once you are over the mountains, you are directed to begin a shallow descent to the airfield at Denver. The cloud cover is deep and you enter a silent world of whiteness. It seems like a long dream as you slip through the clouds.[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="71"][/p] [p]The landing happens before you can think about it. The Windmaster is down on the scrubby, short, mountain airstrip, bumping violently. The landing gear on the starboard side rips off, and the plane spins in a cloud of dust and dry snow. There is a horrible ripping noise as the aft section twists like a piece of paper, jamming the door.[/p] [p]Then there is silence. You quickly hit the switches and cut the ignition to prevent the Windmaster from catching fire. The canopy over the cockpit is jammed too, but Matt – his adrenaline lending him tremendous strength – smashes the catch and forces the Plexiglas plastic bubble open. Cold wind greets you as you all scramble out, dragging Bill with you.[/p] [p]Minutes later you are all huddled in a ramshackle cabin beside the strip. It can barely keep the wind out, but at least you're on the ground and in one piece.[/p] [p]Mimla takes charge.[/p] [p]``Matt, you and Haven gather brush and cover the plane. Otherwise the Doradans will spot it the minute the weather clears. Cover up the landing marks in the snow too.''[/p] [p]She turns to you.[/p] [p]``We've got a serious decision to make.''[/p]

[p]You all agree with Haven not to risk the chance of capture by opening the door. It's time to leave even if it's close to curfew. You split up and take off in different directions in the maze of alleys behind Julio's house.[/p] [p]Weeks later you, and you alone, succeed in getting to Denver with the help of resistance groups in Santa Fe and in the mountains. You never hear from the others again. You deliver the Doradan invasion plans. Later the Turtalian forces set up ambushes and soundly crush the Doradan forces.[/p] [p]When Dorado has been liberated, and you enter Albuquerque along with the Turtalian liberating forces, you are greeted by the thin man who's head of the secret police. He [em]was[/em] a Turtalian agent. The message in the cigarette pack had said to beware of Haven – he was a double agent.[/p] [p]Now begins the hard, but hopeful, task of building a new democratic state in what was once Dorado and is now part of Turtalia.[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p]Going straight to Denver may not be impossible, but you don't want to press your luck. Santa Fe looks like a better bet right now.[/p] [p]You gather everything useful from the Blazer and divide it into manageable bundles. Matt covers the truck with some brush.[/p] [p]The road over the pass and down the other side is easy for walking. You don't think the truck would have made it much farther anyway.[/p] [p]Several times you have to hide in the bushes from Doradan patrols, but you eventually make it to your ``safe house'' in Santa Fe.[/p] [p]Max, your contact in Santa Fe, is disappointed that you didn't make it to Denver, but he's happy you're not dead. As he puts it, ``Hey, you didn't make your escape – but at least you're alive to try again.''[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="74"][/p] [p]You break out of the clouds at about 8,000 feet above the airstrip.[/p] [p]``This is ground control. We have you on visual, Windmaster. Circle once, gear down, airspeed one hundred ten knots, angle of descent about thirty degrees. Easy now. Watch it, your starboard wing is low. That's it. Ease back a bit. Keep it coming. You're doing fine, just fine. Ease back on the stick. Flare a bit more. OK, you got it. Pump the brakes. A bit more. Let her run it out. Keep it on the ground.''[/p] [p]``Well done!''[/p] [p]A jeep scoots out onto the strip with three people in it. One of them is your dad.[/p] [p]``Congratulations!'' he cries. ``You made it. I see you have Mimla safe and sound. – Hey, who is this?''[/p] [p]Haven makes a duck for it, but he's grabbed by two heavily armed soldiers.[/p] [p]``We've heard about you, Haven,'' your dad says to him. ``You're a spy. We'll trade you for one of ours.''[/p] [p]You, Matt, and Mimla are taken to Turtalian headquarters where you are debriefed about the Doradan invasion plans. Mimla can hardly wait to begin setting up a new network of freedom fighters in Dorado. For now, you are all safe and well.[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p]You know that as well as she does. You nod, waiting for her next sentence.[/p] [p]``The problem, of course, is that the pilot can't travel – and we must get out of here.''[/p] [p]You look at Mimla and then at Bill, who is slumped in the comer of the dilapidated cabin: he is obviously in bad shape. There is no way he can walk out.[/p] [p]``What do you suggest, Mimla?''[/p] [p]She looks straight at you, her eyes level and firm.[/p] [p]``That we leave him here with what supplies we have and hope we can get back to him soon enough to save him.''[/p] [p]You don't know what to say. It will probably be a death sentence for him.[/p] [p]Your choice now really is between life and death.[/p]
p.next: Should you leave Bill behind?
Should you stay with Bill and let the others go?

p.text: [p]Matt tries to calm Mimla, but she continues.[/p] [p]``They seem to know our every move. There must be a spy here.''[/p] [p]``Who would do it, Mimla? Those Doradans are mad. They're killers, crooks. Who would work for them?'' you ask.[/p] [p]Mimla shakes her head and almost shrieks.[/p] [p]``That's the point! They corrupt people with money and power. They buy people's souls with it.''[/p] [p][em]Who is the traitor?[/em][/p] [p]You look at Matt. No, it just couldn't be Matt. Julio? No, he's been risking his life for years hiding resistance people. Haven, then? You look at him, ashen-faced and cowering in the corner. He couldn't have the guts to play a double agent. Yet who knows?[/p] [p]Matt, meanwhile, has been looking at you. After all, you are the newcomer to the group.[/p] [p]At any rate, it's time to leave. Staying where you are now is suicide. The Doradans are probably watching you this very minute.[/p]

[p]``No good, Haven. They might be on to your friend. We'll have to make it on our own,'' you say.[/p] [p]The night passes slowly. In the early dawn light you slip one-by-one, at four-minute intervals, into the alley behind the house. Matt is dressed like an old woman and Mimla is wearing the jump suit of a Doradan soldier captured in an earlier raid. You are wearing what you had on – jeans, shirt, light Windbreaker jacket Haven decides to stay behind. You can't say you're sorry.[/p] [p]There's a bus stop right in front of the Doradan Secret Police Headquarters, and you all join the group of waiting people. It's hard to act normal when you could be discovered at any minute. The bus finally comes, though, and the three of you take separate seats. Later you change buses, and by noon you're in Santa Fe. It's amazing, but there wasn't even one security check.[/p] [p]The ``safe house'' is safe! Friends welcome you, Matt, and Mimla. The next day you are off through the mountains to Denver. You know you'll make it![/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p]``It's more important that you and Mimla get to safety,'' Matt says. ``Haven is on his own. His computer codes just aren't as important as you two.''[/p] [p]``Let's go, then,'' you say. You take the important stuff from Haven's pack – a canteen, spare matches, some jerky – and then you set off.[/p] [p]You lead, Mimla follows, and Matt brings up the rear, stopping now and then to erase your footprints with a piece of brush he has cut. Steadily you walk away from the Blazer and toward freedom.[/p] [p]Once a low-flying plane scatters you into hiding.[/p] [p]``Don't look up!'' Matt yells as you dart under the brush. When the sound of the plane recedes in the distance, you ask Matt why he said that.[/p] [p]``A face shows up clearly from the air. Much more clearly than the outline of a person's back. Always look down when someone is searching for you from the air and you don't want to be seen.''[/p] [p]You camp for the night in a dark canyon. The night becomes cold as the sun goes down; you are glad you have blankets. During the night you are awakened many times by the sound of planes overhead, but you are well hidden and you sleep securely.[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="80"][/p] [p]The next day you continue – and so do the air searches. Because of them you are forced to alter your course. You're still going northward, but you have to bear west, rather than east – the direction you want to go.[/p] [p]That night you are tired. The jerky you have for supper does not satisfy you, and you sleep fitfully.[/p] [p]Over breakfast the next day – more jerky – you discuss what to do.[/p] [p]``We're being forced to head towards Canyon de Chelly,'' Matt says.[/p] [p]``Maybe that's not so bad,'' you answer.[/p] [p]``Why?'' asks Mimla.[/p] [p]``Because there are many good hiding places there. We can hole up for a few days. The searches will die down and then we can head the way we want to – toward home and freedom.''[/p] [p]``Sounds good to me,'' says Matt.[/p] [p]You all shoulder your bundles and head off.[/p] [p]Late in the day you find yourself in different terrain. The canyons are steeper and deeper. There is more vegetation. You feel safe – except for a prickly sensation that you're being watched. You keep peering around, but you see nobody. You decide not to tell the others about your hunch – you don't want to scare them.[/p] [p]That night you camp under a cedar tree. The night noises of animals are loud. Suddenly they stop. You hear footsteps approaching.[/p]

[p]Taking Highway 56 seems too risky to you, and Mimla agrees that the pass sounds safer.[/p] [p]``Get thee behind me, Satan Pass!'' you say as you change your direction and head for the mountains on your right.[/p] [p]So far there's been no sign of Doradan troops. You wonder if they think that the four of you were on the plane when they blew it up.[/p] [p]``Say, Matt.''[/p] [p]``Hm?'' Matt says as he turns away from the window.[/p] [p]``We left the engines running on the Windmaster, didn't we?''[/p] [p]Matt thinks a minute. ``Yes, I think we did. In all the confusion I didn't think to turn them off.''[/p] [p]``Neither did I. But listen to this: say you're a Doradan. You're checking out a report on spies escaping by plane. You come over a rise...''[/p] [p]``And the plane is there with its props turning! You blast it to pieces before it takes off!''[/p] [p]``Right! And, of course, everybody on board is killed before they can get away.'' You smile at Matt.[/p] [p]``That's us!'' He grins back at you.[/p] [p]``What about the truck's tire tracks at the ranch – and no truck?'' you ask.[/p] [p]``Accomplices,'' Matt answers quickly, ``who dropped the escapees off and then left.''[/p]

[p]``Right,'' you say. ``We're home free – and I don't mean 'totalitarian freedom,' either.''[/p] [p]``Not quite. We've got to get over those.'' Matt points to the mountains, now very close. ``And it's still a long way to Turtalia.''[/p] [p]``Besides, the Doradans may still be with us,'' Haven adds.[/p] [p]``What do you mean?'' you ask.[/p] [p]``I mean, they may not have followed your line of reasoning. They may be looking for this truck.'' Haven sounds convinced that they are.[/p] [p]``Could be, Haven,'' Matt says.[/p] [p]``You and Mimla better keep your eyes open,'' you tell Haven. ``And you, too, Matt. Now that we're on the road to the pass I don't need your navigating.''[/p] [p]The higher up you go, the worse the road gets.[/p] [p]``This pass sure earns its name if this road's any indication,'' says Matt.[/p] [p]You grunt your agreement; the road has suddenly become a gully, and you're too busy driving around the boulders to talk.[/p] [p]Suddenly the Blazer gives a lurch and the steering wheel jerks out of your hand.[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="84"][/p] [p]You follow the second set of radio instructions.[/p] [p]The Doradan base that sent those instructions directs the patrol planes to your sector, and when you poke above the clouds they force you back to the main base near Gallup. It's all over. Haven grins when the plane lands. He is greeted by the Doradans as one of theirs.[/p] [p]``What a creep!'' you say to Matt and Mimla as the three of you are handcuffed and driven away to some unknown fate – certainly not a good one.[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="86"][/p] [p]``What happened?'' Matt asks as the truck comes to a halt.[/p] [p]``I think we just broke a tie rod.''[/p] [p]You get out to look. Kneeling in front of the truck and peering under, you see that you were right.[/p] [p]``Well, that does it for the Blazer,'' Matt says.[/p] [p]``What do we do now?'' Haven squeaks nervously.[/p] [p]``We walk.''[/p] [p]``Where?'' Mimla asks.[/p] [p]``We're not far from the pass – about a quartermile,'' Matt says. ``We go there first and after...''[/p] [p]``After,'' you continue, ``we either go down the other side, head to the 'safe house' in Santa Fe that I was told about, and then try our escape again – or stay in the mountains and keep trying.''[/p] [p]``But it's hundreds of miles to Denver,'' Haven blurts out.[/p] [p]``Right,'' you reply. ``But it's not impossible.''[/p]
p.next: If you head over the pass to Santa Fe
If you stay in the mountains and keep trying to escape

p.text: [p]You hope Mimla is right as you turn onto Highway 56 and head north.[/p] [p]You decide not to take any chances: you pull off the road and head for cover whenever an airplane approaches. Once, however, Haven fails to spot a plane coming toward his side of the truck. Matt notices it, but it's too late by then. There is nowhere to go, and you are forced to stay on the road in full sight. Nothing happens, though. The plane passes high overhead, and you all breathe a sigh of relief.[/p] [p]Matt yells at Haven, who says nothing except, ``Sorry, I was thinking of something else.''[/p] [p]You wonder what's the matter with Haven. You know he's not stupid. He is scared – it's easy to see – but that should make him more alert, not less.[/p] [p]Matt interrupts your thoughts. ``We're getting close to Chaco Canyon. There should be some good hiding spots there. It's getting late. I think we should stop for the night, find a place to camp, and maybe stay hidden tomorrow. We can travel tomorrow night. It will be easier to hide.''[/p] [p]``Sounds good, Matt.'' You're really beginning to appreciate having Matt along. He has a lot of sensible ideas.[/p] [p]Soon you come to a gravel path that turns off the road, and you follow it. It leads to a small hidden canyon with an overhanging ledge large enough to hide the Blazer and all four of you under it.[/p]

[p]Dinner is brief and not too satisfying, but the beef jerky will keep you going.[/p] [p]You are lying down, trying to sleep, when you hear a twig snap nearby. You open your eyes but don't move. Matt is lying nearby; his eyes are open, too. He winks at you and starts to slide his hand to the submachine gun.[/p] [p]``I wouldn't move, if I were you,'' a low voice says.[/p] [p]Your heart stops.[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="90"][/p] [p]Before you have time to move, a tall figure is in front of you.[/p] [p]``I am here in peace, strangers.'' a deep voice says.[/p] [p]``We are here in peace, too.'' you say.[/p] [p]The figure squats down, but you still can't see him. ``Good. We have something in common. Now, please answer my questions. What are you doing on our land?''[/p] [p]``[em]Our land?[/em]'' you think. You're not sure what to say.[/p] [p]``We're on a hunting trip. We've just camped here for the night.''[/p] [p]``Please answer truthfully.'' the voice says. ``Your future depends on it.''[/p] [p]You pause. You don't know what to do. You're sure there are more people watching and listening. These could be Doradan soldiers trying to trick you, but the speaker doesn't sound like one. Still, you have to know more before you give yourselves away.[/p] [p]``I'd like to ask you a question.'' you say. ``Who are you?''[/p] [p]The figure answers, ``That is fair enough. We will trade questions, but since you are on our land we will go first. You haven't answered my question: What are you doing on our land?''[/p]
p.next: If you decide to trust whoever this is and say, "We are escaping the Doradan Secret Police"
If you decide it's too risky to trust somebody you haven't even seen

p.text: [p]``Matt, here are the codes. Let's go for it.''[/p] [p]``Roger.'' says Matt. ``This is the answer to our prayers. Let's hope it's not phony and we don't end up in a Doradan base.''[/p] [p]``We don't have much choice, do we?''[/p] [p]``No, I guess not OK with you, Mim?''[/p] [p]She nods. You all forget Haven. He is like a piece of baggage – a nervous piece of baggage. Matt keys the mike, stares at his digital watch, and speaks the code words precisely at one-second intervals.[/p] [p]First second: ``OM.''[/p] [p]Second second: ``MANE.''[/p] [p]He pauses for three seconds.[/p] [p]Sixth second: ``PADME.''[/p] [p]He pauses for two seconds.[/p] [p]Ninth second: ``HUM.''[/p] [p]Then he repeats the code, reversing the threesecond and two-second pauses. All ears in the plane are listening intently to the radio, waiting for the response from the land base below.[/p] [p]Sixty seconds pass.[/p] [p]Another thirty.[/p] [p]You feel fear creeping around your neck. Just suppose it was a hoax. Just suppose the land base is preparing to blow you out of the sky.[/p]

[p]Then the message comes across, loud and clear.[/p] [p]``[em]Welcome home[/em] . Repeat. [em]Welcome home[/em] . Our identification code is MANDALA. Repeat. MANDALA. We will guide you in.''[/p] [p]You look around the cabin. Only Haven is not grinning. ``What's [em]wrong[/em] with him, anyway?'' you wonder.[/p] [p]The Turtalians give you landing instructions. Two of the Doradan planes try to follow you in, but Turtalian ground forces shoot them out of the sky.[/p] [p]Your landing is rough – the starboard wing crumples when you skid off the runway – but you are all safe. Turtalian base command greets you. You immediately get medical attention for Bill and hand over the invasion plans. Mimla is already planning renewed activity against the Doradans, and, for now, all is well.[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="94"][/p] [p]You see Matt in front of the Doradan Secret Police Headquarters. Mimla is standing by the corner on the opposite side.[/p] [p]``Hey, you guys, where were you? We'll be late for training.'' Matt shouts it loud and clear and talks with one of the soldiers. They both laugh at some private joke. Then the four of you are together near the jitney stand.[/p] [p]Before long a dun-colored jitney arrives. It is powered by solar cells and isn't too fast, but it works. Not much in this country does. The solar jitneys were left over from pre-Doradan junta days. They were manufactured in Turtalia; the only reason they are still in use is that they are simple and well built.[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="95"][/p] [p]Two hours later you are out on the flatlands. The jitney drops you off near the training site and drives away. No one is there. That's strange. There is a Doradan jeep (also of Turtalian design) next to the site. No one is guarding it. You can see a gas dump nearby – with what look like full jerry cans of gas.[/p] [p]Maybe this is your chance to escape.[/p]
p.next: If you decide to steal the jeep
If you decide to head away on foot

p.text: [p]``OK, Haven, we'll try your scheme. What do we do now?''[/p] [p]Haven smiles a little, a unique gesture for him, and tells you to wait until dawn. He will leave to contact his friend after midnight, when the secret police are usually off the streets.[/p] [p]Matt takes the first guard shift, and you, Mimla, and Julio sleep fitfully in the living room. Outside you hear the occasional rattle of jeeps and the isolated sound of small-arms fire.[/p] [p]Near three A.M. Matt wakes you for your shift. At six A.M. comes the knock at the door you arranged in advance: one short, two long, one short. You open it. There in front of you stand a squad of Doradans. The captain is smoking a thin cigar and smiling.[/p] [p]``Welcome back to the security force of the great Doradan country!''[/p] [p]As you are marched across the street, you catch a glimpse of Haven sitting in an unmarked car. Was he the traitor, or was he unlucky enough to be captured?[/p] [p]You'll probably never know.[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p]You can't leave Haven. You feel responsible for him.[/p] [p]``You guys go ahead. I'm going back to look for him.''[/p] [p]``OK, keep your shirt on. I'll come, too.'' Matt follows you.[/p] [p]Carefully you go back into the house. There is no sound. You cross the tiled kitchen floor and edge up to the living-room doorway. With your back pressed to the wall, you poke your head around the doorway.[/p] [p]``Hands up! Don't move,'' says a familiar voice.[/p] [p]Haven stands in the room surrounded by five Doradan soldiers. He smiles and points a mean-looking laser pistol at you and Matt.[/p] [p]``It's all over. Our men will pick up Miss Mimla in the alley. Let me introduce myself. I am Haven Nightshade – captain, Doradan Secret Police.''[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="98"][/p] [p]You shake free of Haven, and Matt holds him in a firm grip. You ease open the door. Carefully you peer out. The cigarette pack lies crumpled in the gutter a few inches away. You reach out and grab it. The guards across the street look your way, laugh at you, and turn back to their usual routine.[/p] [p]Haven is struggling, but Matt doesn't let go.[/p] [p]Inside the cigarette pack, in a precise hand, is written:[/p]

[p]In a land like Dorado, where terror rules, people begin to trust only themselves. Resistance groups form, but they are broken by informers and spies. Mimla is the strongest leader in Dorado; but the price on her head is very large. She has to get out before someone betrays her again. Her recapture could very well mean the end of any hope of resistance. The will of the people would be broken.[/p] [p]Haven moves forward a little.[/p] [p]``Mimla, I think I can get us out,'' he says. ``I have a friend with a car. Well, it's not a car, actually, it's an old van. I can ask him to come by tomorrow morning and pick us up. He has special government passes to travel to Santa Fe and even further north – he works for the health department There's room for all of us.''[/p]
p.next: If you decide to accept Haven's offer
If you reject the offer and decide to plan your own escape route

p.text: [p class="inlineImage" data-img="101"][/p] [p]No one in the plane talks. Your decision to land in Los Angeles frightens everyone, but you know there are Turtalian emissaries in L.A. They should help you – you hope.[/p] [p]Minutes later three insectlike pursuit helicopters are swarming toward you on your right side. You see the grim and serious faces of the pilots and gunners. At that instant you remember that the Windmaster carries the Doradan military markings that the Turtalian forces painted on for the flight into Dorado.[/p] [p]The radio comes on.[/p] [p]``Attack Leader, one confirmed twin-engined Windmaster bearing Doradan markings. Request permission to destroy!''[/p] [p]There is a moment of silence. You stare helplessly out the windshield at the helicopters. Matt is keying the mike to respond when the answer comes back from the helicopter base.[/p] [p]``Permission given. Destroy intruders.''[/p] [p]It's all over for you.[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="102"][/p] [p]Hiding in the clouds seems like a good idea. You click off the transponder. The silence in the cockpit seems ominous.[/p] [p]The clouds are thick, and the Windmaster slowly disappears into them. You are never seen again.[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p]``Let's get but of here. L.A. sounds like it's a mess. The last thing we need is a combat zone. What do you think, Matt?''[/p] [p]``Roger. Head north.''[/p] [p]The land below you slips by, and soon you are flying over more mountains. Straight ahead are thunder clouds. You slip between the clouds, diving and banking and climbing. It's hard to fly and monitor the compass, altimeter, and fuel – all at the same time.[/p] [p]You begin to feel dizzy as the clouds swirl by. You lose all sense of where earth and sky are. What is up? What is down? Where are you?[/p] [p]Just when you are about to give up all hope, the clouds part. You see an open area below you. This is it![/p] [p]It's rough terrain, but you do a fine job of landing. A wing tip crumples, and the landing gear is battered. Matt hits his head on the control panel and has a small cut, and Haven covers himself with vomit, but the five of you get out alive.[/p] [p]You are in free territory, inhabited by refugees from Los Angeles, survivors from ruined San Francisco, and hardy souls from Dorado. There is a camp about three kilometers from where you landed. The people there feed you, take Bill under their care, and welcome you to their homeland.[/p] [p]Mimla pledges to return to Dorado, but that is for another day.[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p]Stealing the jeep is easy. The keys are in the ignition. There is gas in the cans. Matt drives. Hours pass. Twice you're stopped by Doradan patrols, but strangely enough your luck holds out and you run by without trouble. Julio's false IDs are good ones.[/p] [p]Two days later, after leaving the roads and going cross-country, you enter Turtalian territory. You are FREE – and safe![/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]
