[p]Your mission is too important for you to take a chance with an unseen stranger.[/p] [p]You try to sound casual.[/p] [p]``We're just passing through. You know, hiking, sightseeing, a little hunting.''[/p] [p]``I wish you were telling the truth, but I can see that you are not.'' The voice pauses, then speaks again. ``Hunters, especially three of them, don't carry only one gun – and a machine gun at that. Hikers and sightseers don't sweep away their tracks.'' He pauses again.[/p] [p]You are scared. You had forgotten that feeling you'd had that you were being watched. The voice continues again.[/p] [p]``I will answer your question now. We are Navajos. We live here. I call it our land, but we do not believe that land can be owned. 'Our' is a word we have borrowed from white men. I think you are escaping from the scum – I cannot call them men – who rule Dorado. Do not ask for our help. We will not give it now. Some people do not lie. Those people we trust, even though sometimes it brings our downfall. Those who lie, we shun.''[/p] [p]Another figure steps out of the dark and removes the machine gun from under Matt's blankets.[/p] [p]``We will escort you off our land, and then we will leave you. You will not come back. You are on your own.''[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p]You made a very difficult decision when you left Bill alone in the cabin. But you have the Doradan invasion plans and you must get out. The future of Turtalia and the lives of many people may well depend on your getting those plans out of Dorado.[/p] [p]Outside, Matt studies the flight charts and points to a spot.[/p] [p]``I'll bet this is where we are. It doesn't matter anyway. It's all wilderness. Let's get going.''[/p] [p]For three days you trudge in the face of wind, snow, and fatigue. You become helplessly lost in the merciless mountains. Courage and hope fade; fatigue rules your lives. Haven goes mad and runs off toward imagined safety, leaving you, Matt, and Mimla.[/p] [p]Finally your food is gone. You grow more and more tired, and then become strangely peaceful. The incessant snowflakes seem like little friends.[/p] [p]At last you feel warm, contented, and happy. Mimla and Matt trudge on as you wave good-bye and slump to the ground.[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p]There is nothing you can do. The heat-seeking missile fired at you is on its way. Its sensors reach out and detect a faint glimmer of heat. (You've turned off your engines and the wind has cooled off the exhausts, but a little heat still remains in the engines.) If the missile had hands, it would rub them together now in satisfaction as it homes in on you.[/p] [p]Then it detects an even greater source of heat nearby. Circuits click, relays hum, and the missile instantly changes course, following the exhaust trail of Search One. Seconds later the only thing left of the missile and Search One is a rapidly expanding ball of debris.[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="108"][/p] [p]Search Leader keeps looking for you, but the cloud you're hiding in is even thicker now. You and the plane are totally covered. Eventually Gallup Base calls off the search. You dash for the Turtalian border and freedom![/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="110"][/p] [p]Matt carefully slides his hand away from the machine gun.[/p] [p]``Sit up. Slowly. And keep your hands in sight.'' Everybody obeys. The voice is not friendly. You wonder how many there are besides him and how you were spotted.[/p] [p]You feel something moving through the dark, and a tall form steps into the moonlight outside your shallow cave.[/p] [p]It's not a soldier! You start to breathe a sigh of relief – then stop. ``Who is it?'' you wonder. The military briefing you got before you left Turtalia said there was nobody living in this area anymore. Doradan police used to come out here on ``hunting trips'' and shoot the natives for sport. ``Maybe they didn't kill everybody.'' you think.[/p]

[p]``We'll have to set a time limit if we search,'' Matt says. ``Let's say that if we don't find Haven in ten minutes, we give up. OK?''[/p] [p]``Good. Let's go.''[/p] [p]Shouldering Haven's bundle, you head out to look for him. Since you don't know what direction he went in and there are no footprints, the three of you walk in a spiral pattern.[/p] [p]The terrain is hilly, and you can't see very far. There is no sign of Haven as the ten-minute limit approaches. Then you step over a rise and almost bump into him.[/p] [p]Unfortunately for all of you, Haven is in the company of a platoon of Doradan soldiers. He is not tied up.[/p] [p]``Well, there you are,'' Haven says. ``We've been looking all over for you.''[/p] [p]``We?'' you all say together.[/p] [p]``Allow me to introduce myself.'' He clicks his heels together. ``Haven Nightshade, captain, Doradan Secret Police.'' He bows slightly. ``This time you will not escape.''[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p]``I'm not going to Santa Fe,'' Mimla says fiercely. ``If there's still a chance for escape, we should take it.''[/p] [p]``Well, let's go then.'' you say.[/p] [p]You all grab what you can out of the truck: blankets, food, canteens, rope. Matt covers the Blazer with some brush while the rest of you divide the supplies into bundles that can be easily carried.[/p] [p]Soon you're all ready. You head up to the top of the pass. From there it's easy to see the direction you need to go, and you set off.[/p] [p]You don't get very far that day. By nightfall you're all exhausted from carrying the awkward loads in the high altitude, where there is less oxygen.[/p] [p]You'd like to make a campfire, but you're afraid of being spotted. As you sit in a circle eating, you tell each other stories of atrocities committed by the Doradan Secret Police. They fire you up for escaping, but not for a restful night's sleep.[/p] [p]The next day is like the one before. But then the weather turns bad, and blinding snow forces you to stop early. You take refuge in a cave and watch the snow come down.[/p]

[p]``Give us the knock, Julio.''[/p] [p]``What you want, [em]amigo[/em] ?''[/p] [p]``The special knock. You know it, Julio.''[/p] [p]``Oh, pardon. I have forgotten it. [em]Por favor[/em], open! The curfew!''[/p] [p]At that moment you hear the screech of jeep wheels and the angry shouts of soldiers. There is a burst of gunfire; then the door flies open. You are all captured. Too bad.[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p class="inlineImage" data-img="115"][/p] [p]The cave provides a safe spot to light a fire, and at least you stay warm. But it snows for three days, and the trail becomes impassable. Some good weather is followed by more snow, and the four of you are trapped in the cave.[/p] [p]The food runs out, and finally you starve to death. Haven is the last of all, since he turns cannibal. Eventually, though, he too succumbs, and it is...[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p]``We are escaping the Doradan Secret Police,'' you say.[/p] [p]The figure spits on the ground ``Those scum.'' He pauses. ``I will answer your question now. We are Navajos. This is 'our' land, although Navajos do not believe that anyone can really own the land. Why are the Doradan scum after you?''[/p] [p]``We are – I mean we were – political prisoners. We escaped from one of their jails.'' You want to tell him everything: the fact that you have topsecret information about invasion plans, who Mimla really is, everything – but you can't. ``I would like to tell you more, but I can't. We have to get to Turtalia.''[/p] [p]``I think I understand. Now it is your turn to ask a question.''[/p] [p]You want to ask if he will help you escape, but you know his answer will only be ``yes'' or ``no,'' and you need to know more. Then you have an idea.[/p] [p]``Why will you help us escape?''[/p] [p]You can hear Matt and Mimla chuckle in the dark. Then the voice laughs too.[/p] [p]``Good question. You are assuming we will help. Yes, we will. We will because we hate the Doradans as much as you do. Those scum who come to our villages and shoot our people for target practice, who talk of freedom and practice slavery. We will help because we know the woman who is traveling with you. We will help because we are Navajos.''[/p]

[p]You don't know what to say. All of you are overwhelmed. Finally Matt speaks. ``Thank you.'' Then both Mimla and you say, ``Yes, thank you.''[/p] [p]The voice responds, ``Thanks are not necessary, but you are welcome. Go to sleep now. In the morning we will be on our way. We will take you to Mesa Verde. Our brothers there will help you through the mountains to Denver.'' The figure stands up. You still haven't seen his face.[/p] [p]He speaks again.[/p] [p]``Good night, my friends.''[/p] [p]``Good night,'' you answer.[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]

[p]``We come in peace.'' Matt breaks the silence.[/p] [p]``And my mother is a horse,'' snorts the man holding the gun.[/p] [p]``Wait!'' you shout. All eyes turn to you. Something about the man has triggered a thought.[/p] [p]``We are friends, not fiends,'' you say.[/p] [p]``Friends are always welcome,'' he replies.[/p] [p]``Could you spare some frijoles for a friend?''[/p] [p]The man grins back and lowers his gun.[/p] [p]``[em]Mi casa es su casa[/em],'' he says.[/p] [p]A Turtalian agent! You're saved! It's a good thing you thought of the passwords.[/p] [p]The agent, Miguel, and his compatriots squat in a circle around you.[/p] [p]``We have come down from Mesa Verde on an expedition. We must continue, but I think I can spare Raphael, here'' – he points to a skinny sixteen-year-old boy – ``to help lead you north. Your journey will not be easy, [em]amigos[/em], but you will make it. Let me be the first to welcome you home.''[/p] [p class="end"]The End[/p]
